title: OG-Gaussian: Occupancy Based Street Gaussians for Autonomous Driving
author: Yedong Shen (University of Science and Technology of China), Xinran Zhang (University of Science and Technology of China), Yifan Duan (University of Science and Technology of China), Shiqi Zhang (University of Science and Technology of China), Heng Li (University of Science and Technology of China), Yilong Wu (University of Science and Technology of China), Jianmin Ji (University of Science and Technology of China), Yanyong Zhang (University of Science and Technology of China)
relevance_why: This paper presents a method that utilizes occupancy grids for 3D scene reconstruction in autonomous driving, which could inform techniques for spatial scene modeling relevant to audio-visual environments.
background: Reconstructing realistic 3D scenes of driving environments using data from surround-view cameras and occupancy grids to improve autonomous driving systems.
contribution: OG-Gaussian introduces a novel approach that replaces costly LiDAR point clouds with occupancy grids from camera images, achieving competitive scene reconstruction quality and rendering speed.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods rely on expensive LiDAR sensors and annotated datasets for dynamic objects, which are not cost-effective.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages imagery and occupancy predictions to produce accurate point clouds, thereby eliminating the need for LiDAR data and manual labels.

key_innovation: Utilizes occupancy grids to effectively separate dynamic vehicles from static backgrounds, allowing for enhanced scene reconstruction without requiring expensive equipment.
real_world_impact: This method could significantly reduce costs for autonomous driving systems while maintaining high-quality scene reconstruction, making it more accessible for broader applications.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention any limitations.

new_terms.Occupancy Grid: **Occupancy Grid** is a representation of a 3D environment where each grid cell indicates whether it is occupied or free, commonly used in robotics and autonomous driving for spatial awareness.
